newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Foster's defends Asian strategy after strong profit.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Foster's defends Asian strategy after strong profit.

text.p: Foster's Brewing Group Ltd on Monday forecast continued solid earnings growth after posting a strong annual profit, expressing satisfaction at its performance at home and dismissing concerns about its overseas strategy.

Foster's reported a two percent rise in net profit to A$293.3 million for the year to June 30, despite the absence of income from former British brewing unit Courage, which was sold last August to Scottish and Newcastle.
Courage once accounted for 40 percent of the group's earnings before interest and tax.

Foster's better than expected result included a 16 percent surge in the earnings of its core Australian brewer Carlton and United Breweries (CUB) to A$327 million before interest and tax, on increased market share of 54 percent.
"We have a very solid earnings base and great growth prospects, particularly from CUB and (Australian winemaker) Mildara Blass," chief executive Ted Kunkel said.
The group result exceeded the average market forecast for a pre-abnormal net profit of around A$270 million and confirmed CUB as the groups' growth engine.
Mildara Blass, bought by Foster's in February for A$487 million as part of a foray into the wine business, contributed A$16.1 million to group profit in 1995/96.
Foster's has since used Mildara to take a majority stake in another winemaker, Rothbury Wines Ltd, through a 70 cents per share takeover offer.

"Mildara is on a strong growth track which should see earnings before interest and taxes increase substantially over the next five years and that will be done without the need for further acquisitions," Kunkel said.

But a weak performance from Foster's 40-percent-owned Canadian operation, Molson Breweries, and a A$17.4 million loss on its three Chinese breweries took some of the gloss off the overall result, stock analysts said.
Kunkel called Molson's result an aberration but said competition in the North American beer market remained tough.
"However, Molson has been reorganised and cost have been reduced significantly. This will help our profitability in the future," he told a news conference.
One Sydney-based analyst said the market was also anxious to see Foster's Chinese breweries show signs of improvement.
"Foster's Asia was a much bigger loss than had been flagged," she told Reuters. "They can wear losses, but we don't want to sit around and wait forever."
Kunkel defended Foster's Asian strategy, but said the Chinese breweries were now not expected to turn a profit until 1999/2000.
"Our internal expectations would have had us making a profit in 1998, but I think that's probably been put off by at least a year," he said.

He also confirmed the group's interest in opportunities in India and Vietnam. "We have said quite consistently that we were looking at Asia as a whole and the markets that were most attractive to us...were India and Vietnam," he said
Asked if Foster's was close to a deal in either country, he replied: "We have made some progress." He did not elaborate.
Shaw Stockbroking analyst Michael Heffernan told Reuters Foster's was a world-class brewing business but it needed a major offshore acquisition to ensure long-term growth.
"They have done extremely well in a mature market, but where are they going to get the growth (in Australia), because Lion Nathan are not going to give it to them," he said.
New Zealand brewer Lion Nathan is Foster's chief rival in the Australian beer market.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
